contextId.information: To lay hands on someone is an idiom which means to grab him or to hold onto him. AT: "but no one grabbed him to arrest him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: but no one laid hands on him

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means "everyone who does what I teach" or "everyone who obeys me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means "to obey Jesus." AT: "obey what I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means to experience death. The Jewish leaders mistakenly assume that Jesus is speaking only about physical death. AT: "die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that people used when taking an oath. AT: "In the presence of God, tell the truth!" or "Speak the truth before God!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These are idioms that express the close personal relationship between God and Jesus. AT: "My Father and I are completely joined together as one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the Father is in me and that I am in the Father

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to look up. AT: "Jesus looked up toward heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means that God caused them to be stubborn. AT: "he has made them stubborn" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "put it into the heart" is an idiom that means to cause someone to think about something. AT: "the devil had already caused Judas Iscariot, the son of Simon, to think about betraying Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the devil had already put it into the heart of Judas Iscariot son of Simon, to betray Jesus

contextId.information: This is an idiom. To have a troubled heart means to be worried or anxious. AT: "Stop being so anxious and worried" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Do not let your heart be troubled

contextId.information: "To have a troubled heart" is an idiom that means to be very anxious or afraid. Here Jesus speaks of the heart as if it were a person. AT: "So stop being anxious, and do not be afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Do not let your heart be troubled, and do not be afraid

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means the disciples are very sad. AT: "you are now very sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that speaks of the heart as if it were a person. AT: "you will be very happy" or "you will be very joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This is an idiom that means to look upward. AT: "he looked up to the sky." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he lifted up his eyes to the heavens

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to experience God, rather than just knowing things about God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
